title: Video shows the heartbreaking choices homeless people face every day | Metro News
text:
Nicole Morley for Metro.co.uk Wednesday 15 Feb 2017 3:53 pm A homeless woman sits near Trafalgar Square on January 27, 2016 (Picture: Getty) 
This video outlines some of the heartbreaking choices faced by young homeless people every day. 
The clip depicts the desperate evening of Sam, a teenager who is struggling with a volatile home life. Hundreds of strangers attend funeral of homeless army veteran 
Sam stays out of the house when she can. 
She often stays with friends – although it’s quickly becoming clear that the warm welcome initially offered by their parents’ is growing cold and inconvenient. 
Her request to sleep over at a pal’s house is refused via WhatsApp. 
Unsafe at home, unable to stay at a friend’s house and at the end of a bus route, Sam sends out a plea on Twitter desperate for somebody get back to her before her phone battery runs out. 
Sadly she only receives two responses, one from a concerned friend who’s currently out of town. 
And another, from a man she’s clearly been trying to ignore. 
So, if Sam wants a bed for the night, she must choose between a violent abuser at home and a guy she doesn’t want to sleep with or face a night on the streets. Sam soon feels like she’s outstayed her welcome (Picture: Centrepoint) Sam puts out a plea on Twitter (Picture: Centrepoint) 
Sam’s story is fiction, but it is based on the reality of people Centrepoint work with every day. 
Research conducted by the youth homelessness charity provides a startling look at the decisions vulnerable young people face to avoid sleeping rough. Youth homelessness statistics 
26% of homeless young people have stayed with a stranger. 
12% have committed a crime to be taken into custody to avoid freezing to death. 
9% have attempted to admit themselves in to A&E. 
59% of young people left home following a family breakdown. 
More than 150,000 young people a year across the UK approach their local councils for help with housing, with a third are turned away without meaningful support. Sam is faced by difficult decisions if she wants to stay off the streets (Picture: Centrepoint) 
The Centrepoint Helpline – the first ever advice service for young people who are either homeless or at risk of homelessness – was launched this week by HRH The Duke of Cambridge, the charity’s Patron. 
People between 16-25 are encouraged to call 0808 800 0661 for free and confidential advice about homelessness. More
